Award.AwardTitle: GSE/EXT: Girls RISE (Raising Interest in Science and Engineering) Museum Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Based on nearly two decades of museum programming for low-income Hispanic and African American girls at the Miami Science Museum, this extension service project employs a train-the-trainers approach to build a network of museum-based Extension Agents dedicated to helping informal science educators attract the interest and support the persistence of minority girls, grades 6-12, currently underrepresented in STEM studies. Led by the Miami Science Museum, the collaboration brings together an experienced group of institutions with representation from the informal science, gender research, and engineering communities.

In addition to the Museum, the Expert Project Team consists of key staff from the Association of Science-Technology Centers (ASTC), and SECME Inc. (formerly the Southeastern Consortium of Minorities in Engineering), who serve as the conduit for the participation of minority engineering professional organizations. An advisory/research panel of researchers in gender in STEM, whose work complements those of the project investigators, works closely with the Expert Project Team to prepare Extension Agents from ten geographically dispersed museums, who in turn provide a range of training and peer mentoring services to the practitioner community of informal science educators in science-rich institutions nationwide. Participating museums include: Connecticut Science Center (Hartford, CT), New York Hall of Science (New York, NY), Maryland Science Center (Baltimore, MD), Miami Science Museum (Miami, FL), COSI (Columbus, OH), St. Louis Science Center (St. Louis, MO), Louisville Science Center (Louisville, KY), Sci-Port (Shreveport, LA), Explora (Albuquerque, NM), and California Academy of Sciences (San Francisco, CA).

Specific objectives of the project are to:
- Utilize the national network of science centers and museums to raise awareness and broaden access for girls underrepresented in STEM.
- Develop linkages among organizations with the common purpose of increasing the pipeline of minority female engineers.
- Facilitate the translation of gender and diversity research into practice through a unified training program.
- Provide ongoing services, access to program materials, and tools to broaden the ability of science centers and museum practitioners to provide relevant and engaging programming for girls.

The Girls Rise Network's program of change is tightly focused on increasing the capacity of science centers and museums to interest girls from underrepresented populations in the engineering sciences. It consists of three major processes:
1. Assessing organizational climate with respect to gender, race and ethnicity.
2. Identifying and building community resources related to recruiting, serving and retaining girls in the engineering pipeline.
3. Optimizing the informal science learning environment to engage minority girls in engineering precollege competitions and related programming.

Broader Impacts: The extension services provided through the Girls RISE Museum Network enable museum practitioners to reach a more diverse population, potentially impacting hundreds of girls; and contribute to broader efforts to reduce barriers to minority girls? participation in STEM activities, courses, and majors. In addition, the informal science educators participating in the project benefit from increased awareness and knowledge of cultural differences, resulting in a network of culturally competent educational leaders within the informal science learning community. The project draws from Expert Project Team resources to provide a central repository of high-quality resources for engaging girls, particularly Hispanic and African American girls, in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Girls RISE (Raising Interest in Science and Engineering) Museum Network (Girls RISEnet), a partnership between the Frost Museum of Science, the Association of Science-Technology Centers, SECME, Inc., and a network of ten other science museums located throughout the United States, was funded by the National Science Foundation to address the national need to prepare the next generation of female scientists and engineers. The project focused on strengthening the professional capacity of informal science educators to engage and motivate girls, especially minority girls in grades 6–12, to explore and pursue science and engineering careers.

The initiative had four strategic objectives: 1) utilize a national network of science centers and museums to raise awareness and broaden access for girls underrepresented in STEM; 2) develop links between organizations with the common purpose of increasing the pipeline of minority female engineers; 3) facilitate the translation of gender and diversity research into practice through a unified training program; and 4) provide science center and museum practitioners with ongoing services, access to program materials, and tools to broaden their abilities to provide girls with relevant, engaging programming.

Overall, summative evaluation found strong evidence that Girls RISEnet met its intended objectives. Girls RISEnet developed a successful capacity-building model that made a significant impact. The project provided training and built capacity of over 800 informal educators and more than 1,500 mentors, teachers, parents, and other adults who play a role in supporting girls in STEM pursuits. More than 280 organizations were impacted through regional professional development training. Evaluation data show a low estimate of regional participants’ potential to reach 701,398 girls a year. The project website provided close to 18,000 individuals with resources.

Through a range of activities, it raised awareness about the lack of girls (especially minority girls) in STEM careers, developed staff capacity in each region to develop girl-friendly programming and exhibits, and helped improve STEM access for girls. Professional development delivered at annual national institutes was key in building capacity—raising awareness, knowledge, and skills—to improve access for underserved girls. Relationships developed between regional hubs, institute presenters, and the project team also inspired many regional hub teams to integrate their learning and skills into their organizations.

Evaluation results also showed that the Girls RISEnet program design had several strengths that led to positive outcomes. First, the curriculum provided a cross-section of topics that addressed critical areas needed to build participants’ understanding and skill sets. Second, professional development resources and expert help were available to assist regional hubs in implementing professional development for informal science educators in their regions and supporting educators in putting strategies learned in training into practice. Third, financial resources, in the form of travel awards that supported educators to attend regional training workshops, and provided funds so that regional hubs could bring experts and/or mentors to present at training sessions, and mini-grants that helped 55 recipient institutions expand their capacity to provide effective girl-friendly STEM program. 

Evaluation findings indicated that changes made by organizations to incorporate girl-friendly strategies and develop cultural competence were sustainable. Specifically, by the end of the grant period, regional hubs identified a number of strengths in their abilities to engage girls in STEM activities, including staff expertise, relevant girl-friendly curricula, and making engaging girls in STEM an organizational priority.
